sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Review

Preserving the Past

Every month, people worldwide upload about 6 billion photos to the Internet. Photography is now so common, it is easy to forget that photographs—and the memories they hold—can be very precious.

MEMORY ARCHIVE1

In a cold, windowless basement in Washington D.C., there is a man who knows the real value of a photograph. Since 1983, Bill Bonner has looked after National Geographic’s photo archive. The archive holds around 8 million prints—many over 100 years old.

In his long career, Bonner has looked at hundreds of thousands of photos. He believes each image holds a memory. Some of the pictures record moments in history. Many others, he says, show “people like us, just doing our thing, living our life.” Many of these memories have been forgotten by the outside world. But they still have the power to tell us a lot about the past.

IMAGES FROM THE PAST

When the archive’s earliest photos were taken, photography was difficult and expensive. Photographers needed special equipment and chemicals to develop2 their pictures. Cameras were large and heavy—some weighed 20 pounds (9 kilos) or more. Early explorers used these massive cameras to photograph people and places that most people had never seen.

Photography expeditions took several months, or even years. “They dedicated their lives to this,” Bonner says. Bonner feels responsible for keeping these memories alive, for people now and in the future. Many of the images are fragile, and he has to be very careful to preserve them. For Bonner, these figures from the distant past are almost like his ancestors3. “For me,” he says, “it’s like opening your grandparents’ family album for the first time.”

1archive: n. a place that stores historical material
2develop: v. to make a photograph using a special process
3ancestor: n. someone related to you who lived in the past

items.q: People around the world take about 6 billion photos every month.
The author says that because photographs are so common today, people don’t realize how important they can be.
All of the photos in the National Geographic Archive in Washington, D.C., are over 100 years old.
The photos in the archive include both historic photos and images of day-to-day life.
The author indicates that early cameras were larger and heavier than today’s cameras.
Early photography expeditions could last for months or sometimes years.
Among the photographs in the National Geographic Archive are some photos of Bonner’s ancestors.

sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Extension



Remember This

There is a 41-year-old woman, an administrative assistant from California known as "AJ," who remembers almost every day of her life since age 11. There is an 85-year-old man, a retired lab technician called "EP," who remembers only his most recent thought. She might have the best memory in the world. He could very well have the worst.

"My memory flows like a movie—nonstop and uncontrollable," says AJ. She remembers that at 12:34 p.m. on Sunday, August 3, 1986, a young man she knew called her on the telephone.  She remembers that on March 28, 1992, she had lunch with her father at the Beverly Hills Hotel. She remembers world events and trips to the grocery store, the weather and her emotions. Virtually every day is there. She’s not easily stumped.

There have been a few people over the years with extremely good memories. Kim Peek is said to have memorized nearly 12,000 books (he reads a page in 8 to 10 seconds). "S," a Russian journalist who was studied for 30 years by the Russian psychologist Alexander Luria, could remember impossibly long strings of words and numbers years after he'd first heard them. But AJ is unique. Her amazing memory is not for facts or figures, but for her own life. Indeed, her memory is so unusual and so poorly understood that scientists who have been studying her for the past seven years had to think of a new medical term to describe her condition: hyperthymestic syndrome.

EP is friendly and easy to talk to. He laughs a lot. But in 1960, a virus destroyed the medial temporal lobes in his brain, and with them most of EP's memory. The medial temporal lobes—there's one on each side of the brain—include a part called the hippocampus that turns our experiences into long-term memories. The memories aren't actually stored in the hippocampus—they stay somewhere else, in the brain's outer layer, the neocortex—but the hippocampus area is the part of the brain that makes them stick. EP's hippocampus was destroyed, and without it he is like a digital camera without a working memory chip. He sees, but he doesn't record.

EP can't make new memories, and he can't remember old memories either, at least not since 1960. His childhood, his service in World War II—all that is perfectly clear to him. But to him, gas still costs less than a dollar a gallon, and the moon landing never happened.

items.q: The author mentions specific dates in paragraph 2 in order to . . . a. point out some important events in AJ’s life b. show how good her memory is c. indicate that she sometimes forgets things
Alexander Luria is a . . . a. scientist b. journalist c. lab technician
The sentence “She’s not easily stumped” in paragraph 2 means that AJ rarely . . . a. gives the wrong answer b. responds to questions c. becomes upset
AJ is different to Kim Peek and S because she can remember . . . a. every word that she reads b. long numbers c. details of her own life

The author indicates that the scientists from the University of California . . . a. have never studied someone with a memory like AJ’s b. finally understand why AJ has such an amazing memory c. studied both AJ’s and EP’s memories
EP’s memory problems were caused by . . . a. a war injury b. a disease c. a car accident
According to the article, long-term memories are stored in . . . a. the hippocampus b. the medial temporal lobes c. the neocortex

Why does the author compare EP to “a digital camera without a working memory chip”? a. He can remember images, but he can’t understand words. b. He can remember perfectly, but he can’t speak. c. He can see things, but he forgets them immediately.
EP is most likely to remember . . . a. a family trip he took as a child b. a friend’s wedding in 1970 c. what he had for breakfast this morning

Reading Skills Selfies An article that appeared in Time magazine around two years ago listed the places where people take the most selfies—low-tech photos of themselves. The area with the highest number of selfies per person was Makati City, which is the financial center of Manila in the Philippines. The population of Makati City is about 1.5 million people. People there took nearly 260 selfies per 100,000 persons. Next came Manhattan, a part of New York City. The population of Manhattan is just under 400,000. In Manhattan, people took approximately 200 photos of themselves per 100,000 residents. sections.instructions: DIRECTIONS: Read the excerpt from Cesar Kuriyama’s 2012 TED Talk. Match each question below with the paragraph (A–E) where the answer to the question can be found.
sections.passage:
TED Talk Comprehension

Cesar Kuriyama—One Second Every Day

Paragraph A

. . . So the first of those projects ended up being something I called “One Second Every Day.” Basically, I’m recording one second of every day of my life for the rest of my life, chronologically compiling these one-second tiny slices of my life into one single continuous video until, you know, I can’t record them anymore.

Paragraph B

The purpose of this project is, one: I hate not remembering things that I’ve done in the past. There’s all these things that I’ve done with my life that I have no recollection of unless  someone brings it up, and sometimes I think, “Oh yeah. That’s something that I did.” And something that I realized early on in the project was that if I wasn’t doing anything interesting, I would probably forget to record the video. So the day—the first time that I forgot, it really hurt me, because it’s something that I really wanted to—from the moment that I turned 30, I wanted to keep this project going  until forever, and having missed that one second, I realized, it just kind of created this thing in my head where I never forgot ever again.

Paragraph C

So if I live to see 80 years of age, I’m going to have a five- hour video that encapsulates 50 years of my life. When I turn 40, I’ll have a one-hour video that includes just my 30s. This has really invigorated me day-to-day, when I wake up, to try and do something interesting with my day.

Paragraph D

Now, one of the things that I have issues with is that, as the days and weeks and months go by, time just seems to start blurring and blending into each other and, you know, I hated that, and visualization is the way to trigger memory. You know, this project for me is a way for me to bridge that gap and remember everything that I’ve done. Even just this one second allows me to remember everything else I did that one day. It’s difficult, sometimes, to pick that one second. On a good day, I’ll have maybe three or four seconds that I really want to choose, but I’ll just have to narrow it down to one, but even narrowing it down to that one allows me to remember the other three anyway.

Paragraph E

. . . One of the reasons that I took my year off was to spend more time with my family, and this really tragic thing happened where my sister-in-law, her intestine suddenly strangled one day, and we took her to the emergency room, and she was, she was in really bad shape. We almost lost her a couple of times, and I was there with my brother every day. It helped me realize something else during this project, is that recording that one second on a really bad day is extremely difficult. It’s not—we tend to take our cameras out when we’re doing awesome things. Or we’re, “Oh, yeah, this party, let me take a picture.” But we rarely do that when we’re having a bad day, and something horrible is happening. And I found that it’s actually been very, very important to record even just that one second of a really bad moment. It really helps you appreciate the good times. It’s not always a good day, so when you have a bad one, I think it’s important to remember it, just as much as it is important to remember the [good] days.

a.
Paragraph A
b.
Paragraph B
c.
Paragraph C
d.
Paragraph D
e.
Paragraph E

items.q: Why did Cesar Kuriyama begin his project?
Why will Cesar Kuriyama not forget to work on his project again?
How long is each recording of Cesar Kuriyama’s project?
Why is it sometimes difficult for Cesar Kuriyama to choose which part of his day to record?
Why does Cesar Kuriyama sometimes record bad experiences?
How old was Cesar Kuriyama when he began his project?
What is Cesar Kuriyama’s project?
How long will Cesar Kuriyama’s movie be if he lives to be 80?
